Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS-1007207
Principal Investigator: Matilde Marcolli


This proposal aims at using techniques from noncommutative geometry, especially analytic techniques based on functional analysis, operator algebras, global analysis and index theory, to approach questions of relevance to arithmetic geometry. The main themes covered in this proposal include: the theory of noncommutative tori with real multiplication as a parallel for real quadratic fields to the theory of elliptic curves with real multiplication; the use of quantum statistical mechanical systems associated to number fields and function fields as an approach to explicit class field theory; an application of techniques from functional analysis and quantum statistical mechanics to the study of the asymptotic problem for error correcting codes; the construction of invariants of curves with p-adic uniformization from noncommutative geometry, in terms of index theorems and spectral triples; investigating the relation between motives and noncommutative spaces, in relation to L-functions of varieties and motives; relating the noncommutative geometry approach to the Riemann zeta function to arithmetic topology, matrix models, and foliated spaces; understanding manifestations of modularity on the noncommutative boundary of modular curves.

The project is interdisciplinary in scope, as it is aimed at exploring the interactions between tools and techniques from noncommutative geometry and motivating problems from number theory and arithmetic. This presents a novel approach to classical questions of modern mathematics, where we plan on using techniques and ideas derived from the world of quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, and quantum field theory. Noncommutative geometry is especially suitable as a tool, since it was developed precisely a a geometry adapted to quantum physics: as such, it provides a way to combine quantum mechanical ideas and techniques with more classical algebro-geometric and number-theoretic methods. We expect that a continuing investigation of this approach will lead to further advances and developments within the field of noncommutative geometry itself, by the challenge of fine tuning the available theory to fit specific number theoretic problems, while at the same time it will provide new possible approaches and different viewpoints on questions of number theoretic relevance. This proposal has a strong educational components, with six graduate students involved in various parts of the project. A network of international contacts and collaborations will also be involved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Noncommutative Geometry is a recent field of mathematics (dating back to the early 1980s) which was designed to provide a form of geometry that is adapted to the quantum world, in the sense that it can be made compatible with phenomena such as the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. (A way to formulate this principle mathematically is by saying that position and momentum coordinates do not commute, hence the name "Noncommutative Geometry".) Given its origin, it is not surprising that this form of geometry finds many applications in theoretical physics. It is a lot more surprising that it can be applied to other fields of mathematics, apparently entirely unrelated to quantum physics, such as Number Theory, an ancient subject within pure mathematics that studies the properties and structures of numbers. The intuitive idea behind why Noncommutative Geometry may provide new tools for approaching number theory questions lies in thinking of prime numbers (the building blocks of number theory) as an analog of the creation-annihilation operators of quantum physics. This analogy can be made precise in the construction of quantum statistical mechanical system (a prototype example of this kind is known as the Bost-Connes system) which encodes the properties of certain number theoretic objects (number fields), or of other geometric structures (Riemann surfaces, graphs). Some of the results of this project show that the quantum physics of these systems completely encodes the classical objects, hence number fields (or graphs, or Riemann surfaces) can be entirely reconstructed from knowledge of the associated quantum systems, their partition functions and expectation values. Another advantage of Noncommutative Geometry is the fact that it makes it possible to treat as nice smooth spaces geometric objects that are rugged and irregular like fractals, or that have an intrinsic quantum nature, which makes them fuzzy and not easily describable by classical geometry. Thus, one can extend tools and results of classical smooth geometry and apply them to completely new situations. In this project we extended the real of applicability of Noncommutative Geometry beyond the usual interface of mathematics and theoretical physics, to the realm of Information Theory. We studied how properties of entropy and information can be encoded in algebraic structures, and how phenomena that occur in the theory of computation (such as the halting problem: whether a given algorithm will stop and output a result or run forever) resemble the curse of infinities that plagues the quantum field theory calculations in particle physics, and how similar mathematical structures can model both theories. We also studied how Noncommutative Geometry and quantum statistical mechanical systems can be applied to study the parameterizing space of error correcting codes in Cryptography.
